question: Concurrent administration of quinidine and digoxin results in drug-drug interaction. How does quinidine interact with digoxin?

answers.option: Antagonized the effect of digoxin on the A-V node
Decreased the absorption of digoxin in GIT

question: Which of the following is contraindicated in the left bundle branch block (LBBB)?
Lidocaine, as an antiarrhythmic, produces what effect?
Which of the following conditions is characterized by normal plasma B type natriuretic peptide (BNP) levels?
Which one of the following hypolipidemic drugs, when given orally, is neither absorbed nor metabolized in the intestine?

A 10-year-old boy is a known case of beta-thalassemia major who receives regular blood transfusions. He presents to the emergency room with signs and symptoms of heart failure. Investigations show hemoglobin (Hb) = 8.0gm/dl, serum ferritin = 7000 ng/ml, and serum iron = 250 µg/dL. The echocardiogram shows dilated cardiomyopathy. What is the most likely cause of cardiomyopathy?
What is the most common cause of death following a myocardial infarction (MI)?

An industrialist asks a public health specialist about the measures he can take to control and prevent heart disease among employees. The public health specialist advises on the modifiable risk factors that can be addressed to lower the risk of cardiovascular diseases. Which one of the following options illustrates the modifiable risk factor that the industrialist can focus on?

A patient receiving a class I antiarrhythmic agent on a long-term basis complains of fatigue, low-grade fever, and joint pain suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The patient is most likely using which of the following antiarrhythmic drugs?

A 55-year-old man experiences crushing substernal chest pain after arriving at work one morning. Over the next 5 hours, the pain persists and begins to radiate to his left arm. He becomes diaphoretic and short of breath but waits until the end of his 8-hour shift to go to the hospital. Which of the following laboratory tests has elevated value and would be most useful for the diagnosis of this patient on admission to the hospital?

An elderly patient with a history of heart disease is brought to the emergency room with difficulty breathing. Examination reveals that she has pulmonary edema. Which treatment is indicated using the most potent diuretic?
You are evaluating a patient with rheumatic fever. He had carditis at diagnosis but no residual valvular disease at discharge. How long will you advise for secondary prophylaxis?

answers.option: 10 years or till 40 years of age whichever is longer
2 years or till 21 years of age whichever is longer
10 years or till 21 years of age whichever is longer
5 years or till 21 years of age whichever is longer

question: Which of the following is incorrect for an incised wound?

answers.option: It is always caused by a sharp weapon
The maximum measurement of an incised wound is its length

question: Six months after starting atorvastatin, a patient's total cholesterol and LDL cholesterol concentrations remain above normal and he continues to have anginal attacks despite good adherence to his anti-anginal medications. His physician decides to add niacin. Which of the following is the major recognized mechanism of action of niacin?

answers.option: Increased lipid hydrolysis by lipoprotein lipase
Decreased lipid synthesis in adipose tissue
Increased endocytosis of HDL by the liver
Decreased secretion of VLDL by the liver
Decreased oxidation of lipids in endothelial cells

question: A 54-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with a complaint of chest pain. He has history of hypertension and ischemic heart disease. His blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg, pulse is 70 beats/min, and regular. You add nitrates to his pharmacologic therapy. Which of the following drugs should not be used with nitrates?
Vascular injury is characterized by which of the following responses?

answers.option: Smooth muscle cell migration from media to the adventitia
Shift from contractile to proliferative-synthetic phenotype of smooth muscle cells

question: In which of the following conditions is mid-diastolic murmur heard at the apex?
Which of the following is the cause of the mid-systolic murmur heard at the 2nd right intercostal space?
Which of the following is the cause of early diastolic murmur audible at the 3rd left intercostal space?
A 60-year-old, man with diabetes presents to the emergency room complaining of palpitation and suddenly collapses. Which of the following rhythms needs asynchronous direct cardio current (DCC)?
Concerning ischemic heart diseases, which of the following statements is true?

answers.option: Stable angina results from fixed coronary lesion
Unstable angina is characterized by complete obstruction of the artery
Vasoconstriction can result from increased release of NO
Thrombus is a poor activator of growth-related signals in muscle cell
The death rate in the US from IHD has fallen by one-half since 1980

question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding aneurysms?

answers.option: Atherosclerosis is the most common cause of aneurysms
Morphology of the aneurysms is a good indicator of pathogenesis
Mycotic aneurysms are always true aneurysms
Aneurysms most commonly occur in the peripheral vasculature
The hematoma within a false aneurysm does not communicate with the vascular space

question: A 49-year-old woman has poorly controlled atrial fibrillation. She suffers a 'stroke' and dies. In autopsy, her 600-gm heart is noted to have a mitral valve with partial fusion of the leaflets along with thickening and shortening of the chordae tendineae. There is an enlarged left atrium filled with mural thrombus. Which of the following underlying causes of death is she most likely to have?
Which of the following responses is true concerning myocardial ischemia?

answers.option: Ischemia lasting more than 10 minutes results in irreversible injury
Coagulative necrosis is more important than apoptosis
Loss of contractility occurs within 60 seconds
Irreversible injury initially occurs immediately adjacent to the occluded coronary artery
ATP is reduced to 50% normal in 30 minutes

question: A 63-year-old woman with complains of a sudden onset of pain in the chest radiating to the back. She has a past history of poorly controlled hypertension. On physical examination: heart rate. 90 beats/minute. respirations 20 /minute, temperature 36.8°C. and blood pressure 150/100 mm Hg. No murmurs are audible. A chest radiograph reveals a widened mediastinum. Laboratory findings: total serum creatine kinase of 55 U/L creatinine 0.9 mg/dL, and glucose 123 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Which antihypertensive can cause rebound hypertension on sudden discontinuation?
Which of the following functions is not carried out by the endothelial cells?
Which of the following is not a feature of an atheromatous plaque?

answers.option: Eccentric lesions rather than circumferential lesions
Greater involvement of the abdominal aorta than the thoracic aorta

question: A 45-year-old man is rushed to the hospital following the sudden onset of an episode of crushing substernal chest pain. He develops cardiogenic shock and receives advanced life support measures. An electrocardiogram (EKG) shows chances consistent with a large transmural anterolateral infarction involving the wall of the left ventricle. Which of the following microscopic findings is most likely to be present in this area 4 days following the onset of his chest pain?

A 78-year-old woman has had increasing dyspnea for the past 5 years. On examination, her blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg. Her BMI is 35 kg/m2. Rales are auscultated in both lungs. Her B-type natriuretic peptide, C-reactive protein, and LDL cholesterol levels are elevated. A chest x-ray shows infiltrates in all lung fields and an enlarged heart. Echocardiography shows decreased ejection fraction with segmental wall motion abnormalities. Which of the following forms of cardiomyopathy is she most likely to have?

A 50-year-old man comes to the emergency department with a sudden onset of substernal chest pain. The pain persists for the next three hours. He then becomes breathless and diaphoretic. On physical examination: temperature 37°C, pulse 100/minute, respiratory rate 26/minute, and blood pressure 130/90 mm Hg. A chest x-ray shows a slightly enlarged heart and mild pulmonary edema. An electrocardiogram (EKG) shows ST segment elevation in anterior leads V1-6. Which of the following serum laboratory test findings is most likely to be present in this man?
Which of the following drugs depresses the automaticity of the SA node as well as ectopic foci, abbreviates the action potential duration of Purkinje fibers, and slows A-V conduction?

A 44-year-old woman dies as a consequence of a 'stroke'. At autopsy, she is found to have a large right basal ganglia hemorrhage. She has an enlarged 550 gm heart with predominantly left ventricular hypertrophy. Her kidneys are small, about 80 gm each, with cortical scarring, and microscopically they demonstrate small renal arterioles that have luminal narrowing from concentric intimal thickening. Which of the following is the most likely condition associated with her findings?

A 45-year-old man has had arthritis pain involving all extremities for the past 5 years. He has had worsening orthopnea and pedal edema for 6 months. There is no chest pain. On examination, he is afebrile. A chest radiograph shows cardiomegaly with prominent left and right heart borders, along with pulmonary edema. Laboratory studies show Na⁺ 139 mmol/L. K⁺ 4.3 mmol/L. CI- 99 mmol/L, CO2 25 mmol/L, urea nitrogen 18 mg/dL, creatinine 1.3 mg/dL, and glucose 200 mg/dL. Which of the following additional laboratory test findings is he most likely to have?

answers.option: Hemoglobin of 10.7 g/dL with MCV of 72 fL
Spherocytes on his peripheral blood smear

question: Which of the following drugs has been demonstrated, to retard the progression of left ventricular dysfunction & prolong survival of congestive heart failure patients?

A 49-year-old man has a sudden onset of substernal chest pain with radiation to his left arm. This persists for the next 6 hours. He goes to the emergency department and on examination is afebrile. Laboratory studies show a serum cardiac troponin of 18 ng/mL. Angiography reveals a thrombosis of the anterior interventricular (left anterior descending) coronary artery. During the next 24 hours, which of the following is the most likely complication he will experience?
Which of the following is the most significant feature of the antiarrhythmic action of lignocaine?

answers.option: Suppression of phase-4 depolarization in ventricular ectopic foci

question: Cancer arises from the transformation of normal cells into tumor cells in a multi-stage process that generally progresses from a precancerous lesion to a malignant tumor. These changes are the result of the interaction between a person's genetic factors and three categories of external agents. Considering the external agents, which of the following can be classified as a physical carcinogen?

A 45-year-old man visits a doctor for his concern regarding his risk of heart disease. He explains that his father died of a heart attack at the age of 52 years. He seeks advice on diet. The doctor advises cutting down on the use of certain fats. Which one of the following options illustrates the most important food group to be avoided by the person?

Aging is a natural process with physiological changes, many of them are merely a decline in the rate of functioning. After what age does a reduction in the metabolic rate of about 7% occur every 10 years?

The ultimate goal of the Global Action Plan (GAP) for non-communicable diseases (NCDs) is to reduce the preventable and avoidable burden of morbidity, mortality, and disability due to NCDs to reach the highest attainable standards of health, quality of life, and productivity at every age and those diseases are no longer a barrier to well-being or socioeconomic development. For this goal, GAP defines certain overarching principles and approaches. Which of the following options best outlines one such approach?

A 10-year-old boy is brought to the outpatient department with complaints of high-grade fever for the past 10 days. He also has pain in his right shoulder and right knee. For the past 2 days, he has been experiencing orthopnea. On auscultation, pansystolic murmur is heard. He had a history of upper respiratory tract infection 3 weeks back. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 50-year-old male with chronic hypertension and dilated cardiomyopathy is admitted with chest pain of 4 hours. His electrocardiogram (EKG) shows ST-segment elevation in the chest leads. On angiography, which artery is most likely to be blocked?

A 25-year-old female presents to the outpatient department with a complaint of shortness of breath. Her blood pressure is 110/70 mm of Hg, pulse is 110 per min regular. Cardiovascular examination reveals pansystolic murmur of grade lll that increases on expiration. What would be the most likely clinical diagnosis?

A 45-year-old current smoker presents to the outpatient department with the complaint of pain in calf muscles during walking relieved by rest. His blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Pulse is 70 beats per minute and regular. His baseline investigations are normal, but his lipid profile is deranged. Which type of cholesterol is good for health?

An elderly person with a known history of hypertension presents to the clinic. He informs that he has been taking 50 mg hydrochlorothiazide for a while but it no longer helps in reducing blood pressure. He is given another medicine and a spontaneous fall in systolic blood pressure is seen. What is the medication?
In aortic regurgitation, systolic blood pressure in the lower limbs, 20 mm Hg higher than the upper limbs is noted in which of the following signs?
Left ventricular hypertrophy is diagnosed with what value of SV1+RV5 according to voltage criteria?

A 47-year-old man with history of hypertesnion presents to the emergency room with the complaint of severe sub-sternal chest pain on mild exertion since morning. His electrocardiogram (ECG) shows ST elevation in chest leads. He is treated for an acute anterior wall myocardial infarction. What is the recommended dose of aspirin to support primary percutaneous coronary intervention?
Which of the following is correct regarding age and color of a bruise?
Which of the following is incorrect regarding a stab wound?

answers.option: In this injury bruising around the opening of the wound is seen
It is a wedge shaped opening wound
It results from piercing with a pointed weapon
It may occur with a knife

question: What is the time from diagnosis of cancer to death known as?
Which of the following is not a part of the ACS protocol?
A few seconds after myocardial infarction (MI), aerobic respiration ceases which leads to the formation of which of the following noxious substances?
Which of the following enzymes, when not present, will sensitize an individual to even a small dose of alcohol?
Which of the following is used as an antidote for digoxin poisoning?
Which of the following is not a factor included in the thrombolysis in myocardial infarction (TIMI) risk score?

answers.option: Prior history of coronary stenosis of ≥ 50%
Presence of at least three risk factors for coronary artery disease
Aspirin use in the past seven days

question: Which of the following best describes the physiological process occurring in a person having a myocardial infarction (MI)?

answers.option: Local nervous reflex mediated episodic coronary vessel muscle relaxation
Constriction of coronary vessels caused by low blood oxygen
Diminished blood flow to the heart is not enough to meet the oxygen demand of the tissue despite collateral formation

question: What is the heart sound that is not too loud but has a thrill called?
Which of the following drugs decreases heart rate but has no vasodilatory effect?

A 25-year-old woman presents to the clinic with shortness of breath, swollen feet, and fatigue. An echocardiogram demonstrates a dilated right ventricle and a normal left ventricle. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is infrequently classified as acute coronary syndrome (ACS)?
Which of the following decreases mortality in acute coronary syndrome (ACS) patients in the emergency room?
A female patient underwent surgery for left axillary node removal after which she developed swelling in her left hand. There is no pain or discoloration. What is the diagnosis?
A patient with pneumonia, who has been bedridden for a long time, has developed swelling in his left leg which hurts to move. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A young male presents to the outpatient department with swelling in his legs and scrotum. On physical examination, his inguinal lymph nodes are enlarged and tender. Which of the following organisms is most likely to be responsible for the patient's condition?
Which of the following is a class IA antiarrhythmic drug?
